citations.narrative:
During inspection, there was a section of the raised floor in the outdoor part of the third enclosure on the south side of the
sheltered housing building for the French Bulldogs with section of grating the had come loose from building under the
entrance to the indoor portion of the enclosure. This creates a vertical triangular gap about 4 foot long and about 8 inches
at the building end.
This gap creates an injury and entrapment risk for the French Bulldog housed in the enclosure.
Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound. They must be kept in
good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury.
To be corrected by: February 14th, 2025

In the main housing building there was a open box of dog treats that was not stored in a leak proof container.
In the secondary building housing the adult French bulldogs where were two open bags of food sitting on the floor next to
the rusted metal trash can that was storing additional food.
A rusted food barrel causes a risk of contamination to the food stored within. Food a treats that are stored in open bags
are boxes lead to contamination and spoilage of the food either from exposure to the environment or by drawing pests
such as rodents.
Supplies of food and bedding must be stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, and
vermin infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and
around the supplies. Food must be stored in a manner that prevents contamination and deterioration of its nutritive value.
All open supplies of food and bedding must be kept in leakproof containers with tightly fitting lids to prevent contamination
and spoilage.
To be corrected by: February 12th, 2025

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The secondary building containing the sheltered housing enclosures for two adult bulldogs was not being adequately
cleaned or sanitized. There was a caked on buildup of debris and oils from the dogs on the walls, floors, and doors of the
indoor portion of the enclosures. On the north side of the building the outdoor runs were stone and there were large piles
of accumulated feces in all the occupied enclosures.
Failure to provide adequate cleaning and sanitization in the primary enclosures increases the risk of disease transmission,
attracts insects/pests, and increases odors. Excreta could potentially cause soiling on the body of the dog being housed in
the affected enclosure. The licensee must remove excreta and food waste from the primary enclosure daily and from
under the primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent an excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to
prevent soiling of the dogs contained in the primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests and odors.
To be corrected by: February 12th, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
During inspection, there was a section of the raised floor in the outdoor part of the third enclosure on the south side of the 
sheltered housing building for the French Bulldogs with section of grating the had come loose from building under the 
entrance to the indoor portion of the enclosure. This creates a vertical triangular gap about 4 foot long and about 8 inches 
at the building end.  
This gap creates an injury and entrapment risk for the French Bulldog housed in the enclosure.  
Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound. They must be kept in 
good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury. 
To be corrected by: February 14th, 2025 
3.1(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
In the main housing building there was a open box of dog treats that was not stored in a leak proof container.  
In the secondary building housing the adult French bulldogs where were two open bags of food sitting on the floor next to 
the rusted metal trash can that was storing additional food.  
A rusted food barrel causes a risk of contamination to the food stored within. Food a treats that are stored in open bags 
are boxes lead to contamination and spoilage of the food either from exposure to the environment or by drawing pests 
such as rodents.  
Supplies of food and bedding must be stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, and 
vermin infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and 
around the supplies. Food must be stored in a manner that prevents contamination and deterioration of its nutritive value. 
All open supplies of food and bedding must be kept in leakproof containers with tightly fitting lids to prevent contamination 
and spoilage.  
To be corrected by: February 12th, 2025 
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The secondary building containing the sheltered housing enclosures for two adult bulldogs was not being adequately 
cleaned or sanitized. There was a caked on buildup of debris and oils from the dogs on the walls, floors, and doors of the

indoor portion of the enclosures. On the north side of the building the outdoor runs were stone and there were large piles 
of accumulated feces in all the occupied enclosures. 
Failure to provide adequate cleaning and sanitization in the primary enclosures increases the risk of disease transmission, 
attracts insects/pests, and increases odors. Excreta could potentially cause soiling on the body of the dog being housed in 
the affected enclosure. The licensee must remove excreta and food waste from the primary enclosure daily and from 
under the primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent an excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to 
prevent soiling of the dogs contained in the primary enclosures, and to reduce disease hazards, insects, pests and odors. 
To be corrected by: February 12th, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
